Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Challenges in Probing Dark Energy with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope
Award.AbstractNarration:
The standard models of particle physics and cosmology are incomplete. The particle content does not contain a viable candidate for the dark matter in the Universe and there is no well-motivated explanation of the nature of dark energy. The fields of particle physics and cosmology are inextricably intertwined. Accelerator-based experiments, detectors in deep underground mines, and telescopes in space and on the ground are all needed and used to explore fundamental questions such as the nature of dark matter. Gravitational lensing is a cosmological probe that has the advantage of being sensitive to all matter in the Universe: baryonic and dark matter. The growth of dark matter structure is a sensitive probe of the physics of dark energy.

With this award, the Stanford group will play a leadership role in a high-priority effort in observational cosmology through the proposed Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) and the LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration. The LSST is the first ground-based telescope being designed from scratch to address the severe demands on systematic uncertainties needed to fully exploit weak gravitational lensing as a cosmological probe. The LSST will also address cosmological questions through studies of the growth of large scale structure, baryon acoustic oscillations and Type Ia supernovae. The group will study the experimental challenges to achieving the maximum sensitivity to dark energy through several observational probes, with a focus on gravitational lensing. This effort will be based on analytical and computational techniques, and on detailed simulations of the LSST system. They will contribute to the development of high fidelity simulations and, where appropriate, use existing imaging data to develop and test the understanding of systematic effects that will impact LSST.

The work with LSST simulations and astronomical data provides opportunities for students and postdocs to gain skills in statistics, data analysis, and handling large data sets that are in high demand in the private and public sectors. The PI brings her strong targeted efforts in education and advising, aimed at increasing and diversifying the cohort of students who pursue degrees in physics and engineering, and broadening career paths for physicists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes for the Stanford group led by Principle Investigator Patricia Burchat are focused on preparing for state-of-the art cosmological measurements related to dark matter and dark energy with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (currently under construction) -- through the LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration (DESC). The group has conducted detail studies of experimental challenges that must be overcome to achieve the maximum sensitivity to dark energy through the observational probe of gravitational lensing.

Gravitational lensing is a powerful cosmological probe that has the advantage of being sensitive to all matter in the Universe:  ``regular matter'' and dark matter. The growth of dark matter structure is a sensitive probe  of the physics of dark energy. The LSST is the first ground-based telescope designed from the bottom up to address the severe demands on systematic uncertainties needed to fully exploit weak gravitational lensing as a cosmological probe.  Meeting those demands and delivering the science requires an unprecedented understanding of systematic effects, which the Stanford group has been addressing with this NSF support.  This deeper understanding also benefits other dark energy probes the DESC will use to address cosmological questions -- including galaxy cluster cosmology. 

The Stanford group's NSF-supported research has involved the development of analytical and computational tools, and targeted, high-fidelity simulations to test our understanding of  systematic biases and uncertainties related to effects that will potentially limit the sensitivity of the LSST to measurements of galaxy shapes for weak lensing science -- from the strict demands on understanding the point spread function, including subtle atmospheric and chromatic effects, to the impact of the very high density of sources the LSST will image (``blended'' objects). In these studies, every effort has been made to document and make public the studies, including the software for quantifying and remediating galaxy shape biases. The group has contributed to collaborative open-access projects whenever possible -- to have the broadest research impact.  The work with LSST simulations and astronomical data provides opportunities for students and postdocs to gain skills in statistics, data analysis, and handling large data sets, that are all in high demand in the private and public sectors.

Using her  leadership experience in particle physics, the PI has been active in helping establish the LSST DESC as a scientific collaboration that works together to maximize the impact of the LSST survey on dark energy science.  The PI has been the main organizer of a successful set of ongoing Dark Energy Schools associated with LSST DESC meetings, with videos and other resources for 25 lessons spread over six Schools now available on a public web page (http://www.lsst-desc.org/DEschool).
